title: Costa Group an 'industrial' company? Yeah right
text:
Pitching the market Costa’s $1 billion float in 2015, chief executive Harry Debney assured potential investors that its use of protected cropping and hydroponics meant the fruiterer was not really a primary producer. These guys were onto the whole “because technology” sham as early as Domino’s, and years before Corporate Travel and Latitude.

"We decided the smartest thing to do was … really develop a lot of [intellectual property] and to move away from the vagaries of the weather,'' Debney told The Sydney Morning Herald. "We would argue that we are more of an industrial profile than an agricultural profile."

Harry Debney and Frank Costa in happier times. Josh Robenstone

Total BS, as it turns out. Australia is again in drought and Costa is again at its mercy. ‘Twas ever thus.

Unveiling its fourth downgrade this year on Monday, Costa cited “prolonged extreme dry and hot conditions” as the predominant reason for its meagre crop and “a moderate improvement of dry weather and drought conditions in Australia and more normal and seasonal crop cycles” as key to meeting its 2020 forecast (betting on fairer weather having gone so well for Bega, AACo and Nufarm in recent times). To The Australian, Frank Costa bemoaned that “before we went public these things happened and you didn’t have to tell anybody.” Industrial profile, eh?

At least one investor didn’t wait around to see how Harry’s rain dance would eventuate.
